page.title: 03HISTORY OF CUMBERNAULD
page.content: {Cumbernauld}takes its name from the Gaelic,{Cumar_nan_alt},meaning the confluence of the waters.The town lies close to the headwaters of the Luggie water (which flows west to the Kelvin and Clyde)and the Red Burn (which flows to the Carron and the Forth), and stands on the{watershed {of Scotland}. The town lies just south of the Antonine Wall and was on the frontier of the {Roman Empire.} In Norman Times it was owned by the { {COMYN}family, but passed to the { {Flemings}for their support of{Robert {the Bruce.}During the middle ages the Flemings were strong supporters of the Stuarts and in 1561{Mary Queen of {Scots}visited the town and stayed at the castle.During the{civil war}the Flemings fought for the king and aided {Montrose}at the{Battle of Kilsyth.
